member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.Unity.PerRequestLifetimeManager
member.summary: A that holds onto the instance given to it during the lifetime of a single HTTP request. This lifetime manager enables you to create instances of registered types that behave like singletons within the scope of an HTTP request. See remarks for important usage information.

remarks.para: Although the lifetime manager works correctly and can help in working with stateful or thread-unsafe dependencies within the scope of an HTTP request, it is generally not a good idea to use it when it can be avoided, as it can often lead to bad practices or hard to find bugs in the end-user's application code when used incorrectly. It is recommended that the dependencies you register are stateless and if there is a need to share common state between several objects during the lifetime of an HTTP request, then you can have a stateless service that explicitly stores and retrieves this state using the collection of the object.

For the instance of the registered type to be disposed automatically when the HTTP request completes, make sure to register the with the web application. To do this, invoke the following in the Unity bootstrapping class (typically UnityMvcActivator.cs): DynamicModuleUtility.RegisterModule(typeof(UnityPerRequestHttpModule));
